Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2011 01:21AM geowys wrote: THANK YOU!  I've been in a mood tonite and I needed your post! Hugs
Posts.Title: 18 1/2 years and counting (for Fitztwins) Kathy36 Banana83

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2011 11:04PM geowys wrote: When my nails were lifting off the Nurse Practioner told me the mix for Plain White Vinegar and warm water, 1 /4or 5 parts.  It keeps the white section from the sinking into the pink look.  It destroys something that builds up under the nail (can't remember word).  At one point I saw a dematologist (surprised me that who was recommended by the Doctor) because I did have an infection that started with smelly oozing then began to turn black and green. I did a round of antibiotics and things cleared up.  I still do the soak maybe 2 times a week and keep the nails short.  I wear disposable gloves for gardening and even doing the dishes.  The neuropathy sometimes interferes with my embroidery machine work but that's okay.  Had to drop clinical trial which included Avastin because, like others, severe nosebleeds. Lumpectomy,chemo & radiation 2004, 5 yrs arimedex, 2010 Stage 4 with liver mets and chemo.  My current cocktail is Abraxane every other week with a dose of Bendryl and corticosteroids.
Posts.Title: Nail Issues Due to Chemo KAM1 lago

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2012 04:17PM geowys wrote: I do Halaven on Mondays, nurse injets armful of neupogen on Tuesday, (prilosec daily as well as other vitamns and oils, arthritis, etc.), and have shifted from 2 weeks on 1 off to every other week because of the neuropathy.  CA15-3 has dropped from 325 to 70.8.  Nothing new in all pictures. Latest problems are with UTI's (and a little spotting at age 59) and while on Warfarin can't drink much cranberry juice. The best thing going on is I scheduled a train trip thru New England foliage with some friends.  Been putting off any vacation for way too long.  Although Illinois has beautiful Autumns I have never been East and am looking forward to seeing my first lighthouse and fresh lobster dinner. Definately has lifted my spirits and something to look forward to besides more treatments, CT's, PET's etc. Dr is giving a 1 week break before trip to allow hands/feet to improve.  Figured the tiredness bouts will be accomodated by being on a train -- taking a small pillow.  Will smile a lot between naps.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2012 04:15PM geowys wrote: alesta29: I get Benadryl in my cocktail (because of itching) and I sleep from it (during and after infusion) so I'm not sure  about Halaven and sleep.  Do you have other drugs in your cocktail?  I do get really tired easily, daily, moreso on the Halaven than any other chemo regiment.  I also get dehydratd easily tho I drink water etc constantly.  Have had to go in for IV fluids a few times this last couple weeks.
Posts.Title: Halaven - Day 1 PJB Wanderingneedle

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 08:07PM geowys wrote: Onc never gave me a timeline. A nurse in a clinical trial informed me I'd be on chemo the rest of my life.  I researched lifespans.  I cried.   I still wonder with every new pain or infection or treatment change "Is this it?"  But the more I make it through those bad times I think statistics be d..d   I've been stage IV over two years now.  June, 2010 I figured I'd never put up another Christmas tree.  My Dad went to bed one night and never got up in the morning.  My Mom had multiple strokes and lived over 3 years in a nursing home. No one knows.  Each morning I rub my dog's head and say "We've got another day." I stick Jimmy Buffet in the dashboard and tell myself there's "still so much to be done."  The one thing that gives me the most hope is that new things are being discovered daily.  In 2004 with the surgery, chemo and radiation  I didn't know so many treatment plans would ever exist!  Maybe I should bake cakes on the birthdays of Arimedex, Halaven etc.
Posts.Title: Reflections on "Cancerversaries"... what have you learned? K-Lo Fitztwins

Posts.Content: geowys wrote: Oncology is on a wait and see attitude with my spotting.  Haven't had a mentrual flow since first chemo in 2004.  Have had UTI's a couple times and dehydration intermittently.  Maybe the dehydration is the cause of the spotting according to one NP. It had followed being on an antibiotic for a UTI.  Then maybe it's related to the coumadin/warfarin I've been taking for months to ward off blood clots (very bumpy veins on leg tho passed a sonogram okay).  So not a very nice subject but has anyone delt with spotting?
